# Heart (symbol)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Beating_Heart.gif)](/wiki/File:Beating_Heart.gif)

An [animated](/wiki/Animation "Animation") beating heart

The **heart shape** (â™¥) is an [ideograph](/wiki/Ideograph "Ideograph") used to
express the idea of the "heart" in its [metaphorical](/wiki/Heart_\(metaphor\)
"Heart \(metaphor\)") or [symbolic](/wiki/Symbol "Symbol") sense as the center
of [emotion](/wiki/Human_emotion "Human emotion"), including
[affection](/wiki/Affection "Affection") and [love](/wiki/Love "Love"),
especially (but not exclusively) [romantic love](/wiki/Romantic_love "Romantic
love").

The "wounded heart" indicating [love sickness](/wiki/Love_sickness "Love
sickness") came to be depicted as a heart symbol pierced with an arrow
([Cupid](/wiki/Cupid "Cupid")'s), or heart symbol "broken" in two or more
pieces.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Heart_\(symbol\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

### Earliest
use[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Heart_\(symbol\)&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Earliest use")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Roman_de_la_poire_heart_metaphor.jpg/220px-
Roman_de_la_poire_heart_metaphor.jpg)](/wiki/File:Roman_de_la_poire_heart_metaphor.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Roman_de_la_poire_heart_metaphor.jpg "Enlarge")

The earliest known visual depiction of a heart symbol, as a lover hands his
heart to the beloved lady, in a manuscript of the _[Roman de la
poire](/wiki/Roman_de_la_poire "Roman de la poire")'mid-13th century._

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Pisano_Charity.jpg/220px-
Pisano_Charity.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pisano_Charity.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Pisano_Charity.jpg "Enlarge")

[Andrea Pisano](/wiki/Andrea_Pisano "Andrea Pisano")'s
_[Charity](/wiki/Florence_Baptistery#Andrea_Pisano "Florence Baptistery")_ (c.
1337), holding a heart in her right hand.

The combination of the heart shape and its use within the heart metaphor
developed at the end of the [Middle Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages"),
although the shape has been used in many ancient epigraphy monuments and
texts. With possible early examples or direct predecessors in the 13th to 14th
century, the familiar symbol of the heart representing love developed in the
15th century, and became popular in Europe during the 16th.[1] Before the 14th
century, the heart shape was not associated with the meaning of the heart
metaphor. The geometric shape itself is found in much earlier sources, but in
such instances does not depict a heart, but typically foliage: in examples
from antiquity [fig](/wiki/Common_fig "Common fig") leaves, and in medieval
iconography and heraldry typically the leaves of ivy and of the water-lily.

The first known depiction of a heart as a symbol of romantic love dates to the
1250s. It occurs in a miniature decorating a capital 'S' in a manuscript of
the French _[Roman de la poire](/wiki/Roman_de_la_poire "Roman de la poire")_
(National Library FR MS. 2086, plate 12). In the miniature a kneeling lover
(or more precisely, an allegory of the lover's "sweet gaze" or _douz regart_)
offers his heart to a damsel. The heart here resembles a pine cone (held
"upside down", the point facing upward), in accord with medieval anatomical
descriptions. However, in this miniature what suggests a heart shape is only
the result of a lover's finger superimposed on an object; the full shape
outline of the object is partly hidden, and therefore unknown. Moreover, the
French title of the manuscript that features the miniature translates into
"Novel Of The Pear" in English. Thus the heart shaped object would be a pear;
the conclusion that a pear represents a heart is dubious. Opinions therefore
differ over this being the first depiction of a heart as symbol of romantic
love.[2] [Giotto](/wiki/Giotto "Giotto") in his 1305 painting in the
[Scrovegni Chapel](/wiki/Scrovegni_Chapel "Scrovegni Chapel")
([Padua](/wiki/Padua "Padua")) shows an [allegory of
charity](/wiki/Charity_\(virtue\) "Charity \(virtue\)") handing her heart to
Christ, this heart is also depicted in the pine cone shape based on anatomical
descriptions of the day (still held "upside down"). Giotto's painting exerted
considerable influence on later painters, and the motive of Caritas offering a
heart is shown by [Taddeo Gaddi](/wiki/Taddeo_Gaddi "Taddeo Gaddi") in Santa
Croce, by [Andrea Pisano](/wiki/Andrea_Pisano "Andrea Pisano") on the bronze
door of the south porch of the Baptisterium in Florence (c. 1337), by
[Ambrogio Lorenzetti](/wiki/Ambrogio_Lorenzetti "Ambrogio Lorenzetti") in the
Palazzo Publico in Siena (c. 1340) and by [Andrea da
Firenze](/wiki/Andrea_da_Firenze "Andrea da Firenze") in Santa Maria Novella
in Florence (c. 1365). The convention of showing the heart point upward
switches in the late 14th century and becomes rare in the first half of the
15th century.[2]

The "scalloped" shape of the now-familiar heart symbol, with a dent in its
base, arises in the early 14th century, at first only lightly dented, as in
the miniatures in Francesco Barberino's _Documenti d 'amore_ (before 1320). A
slightly later example with a more pronounced dent is found in a manuscript
from the Cistercian monastery in Brussels (MS 4459â€“70, fol 192v. Royal Library
of Belgium). The convention of showing a dent at the base of the heart thus
spread at about the same time as the convention of showing the heart with its
point downward.[3] The modern indented red heart has been used on [playing
cards](/wiki/Playing_cards "Playing cards") since the late 15th century.[4]

Various hypotheses attempted to connect the "heart shape" as it evolved in the
late medieval period with instances of the geometric shape in antiquity.[5]
Such theories are modern, proposed from the 1960s onward, and they remain
speculative, as no continuity between the supposed ancient predecessors and
the late medieval tradition can be shown. Specific suggestions include: the
shape of the seed of the [silphium](/wiki/Silphium "Silphium") plant, used in
ancient times as an [herbal contraceptive](/wiki/Herbal_contraceptive "Herbal
contraceptive"),[5][6] and stylized depictions of features of the human female
body, such as the female's [buttocks](/wiki/Buttocks "Buttocks"), [pubic
mound](/wiki/Mons_pubis "Mons pubis"), or spread [vulva](/wiki/Vulva
"Vulva").[7]

### Renaissance and early
modern[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Heart_\(symbol\)&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Renaissance and early modern")]

Hearts can be seen on the bible Jesus holds in the [Empress
Zoe](/wiki/Zoe_Porphyrogenita "Zoe Porphyrogenita") mosaic in the [Hagia
Sophia](/wiki/Hagia_Sophia "Hagia Sophia") in Istanbul. It probably dates from
1239.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Empress_Zoe_mosaic_Hagia_Sophia.jpg/220px-
Empress_Zoe_mosaic_Hagia_Sophia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Empress_Zoe_mosaic_Hagia_Sophia.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Empress_Zoe_mosaic_Hagia_Sophia.jpg "Enlarge")

Mosaic of the Empress Zoe in the Hagia Sophia, 1239

Hearts can also be seen on various stucco reliefs and wall panels excavated
from the ruins of [Ctesiphon](/wiki/Ctesiphon "Ctesiphon"), the
[Persian](/wiki/Sasanian_Empire "Sasanian Empire") capital (circa 90 BC â€“ 637
AD).[8][9][10]

The [Luther rose](/wiki/Luther_rose "Luther rose") was the
[seal](/wiki/Seal_\(device\) "Seal \(device\)") that was designed for [Martin
Luther](/wiki/Martin_Luther "Martin Luther") at the behest of Prince [John
Frederick](/wiki/John_Frederick_I,_Elector_of_Saxony "John Frederick I,
Elector of Saxony"), in 1530, while Luther was staying at the
[Coburg](/wiki/Coburg "Coburg") Fortress during the [Diet of
Augsburg](/wiki/Diet_of_Augsburg "Diet of Augsburg"). Luther wrote an
explanation of the symbol to [Lazarus Spengler](/wiki/Lazarus_Spengler
"Lazarus Spengler"): "a black cross in a heart, which retains its natural
color, so that I myself would be reminded that faith in the Crucified saves
us. 'For one who believes from the heart will be justified' (Romans
10:10)."[11]

The [aorta](/wiki/Aorta "Aorta") remains visible, as a protrusion at the top
centered between the two "chambers" indicated in the symbol, in some
depictions of the Sacred Heart well into the 18th century, and is partly still
shown today (although mostly obscured by elements such as a crown, flames,
rays, or a cross) but the "hearts" suit did not have this element since the
15th century.

The heart symbol reached Japan with the [Nanban trade](/wiki/Nanban_trade
"Nanban trade") of 1543 to 1614, as evidenced by an [Edo
period](/wiki/Edo_period "Edo period") [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai_armor "Samurai
armor") helmet (dated c. 1630), which includes both the rounded and indented
forms of the heart symbol, representing the heart of
[Marishiten](/wiki/Marici_\(Buddhism\) "Marici \(Buddhism\)"), goddess of
archers.[12]

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/CordierColor.jpg/94px-CordierColor.jpg)](/wiki/File:CordierColor.jpg)

The chanson _Belle, Bonne, Sage_ by [Baude Cordier](/wiki/Baude_Cordier "Baude
Cordier"), written in the shape of a heart, in the [Chantilly
Codex](/wiki/Chantilly_Codex "Chantilly Codex"). This is one of two dedicatory
pieces placed at the beginning of the older (late 14th century) corpus,
probably to replace the original first fascicle, which is missing.

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Sacr%C3%A9-Coeur_K%C3%B6ln.jpg/120px-Sacr%C3%A9-Coeur_K%C3%B6ln.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sacr%C3%A9-Coeur_K%C3%B6ln.jpg)

### Modern[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Heart_\(symbol\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Modern")]

Since the 19th century, the symbol has often been used on [St. Valentine's
Day](/wiki/St._Valentine%27s_Day "St. Valentine's Day")
[cards](/wiki/Greeting_card "Greeting card"), [candy](/wiki/Candy "Candy")
boxes, and similar [popular culture](/wiki/Popular_culture "Popular culture")
artifacts as a symbol of [romantic love](/wiki/Romantic_love "Romantic love").

The use of the heart symbol as a [logograph](/wiki/Logograph "Logograph") for
the English verb "to love" derives from the use in "[I â™¥
NY](/wiki/I_%E2%99%A5_NY "I â™¥ NY")," introduced in 1977.[13]

Heart symbols were used to symbolize ["health" or
"lives"](/wiki/Health_\(gaming\) "Health \(gaming\)") in [video
games](/wiki/Video_games "Video games"); influentially so in _[The Legend of
Zelda](/wiki/The_Legend_of_Zelda "The Legend of Zelda")_ (1986). _[Super Mario
Bros. 2](/wiki/Super_Mario_Bros._2 "Super Mario Bros. 2")_ (1987, 1988) had a
"life bar" composed of hexagons, but in 1990s remakes of these games, the
hexagons were replaced by heart shapes. Since the 1990s, the heart symbol has
also been used as an ideogram indicating health outside of the video gaming
context, e.g. its use by restaurants to indicate heart-healthy nutrient
content claim (e.g. "low in [cholesterol](/wiki/Cholesterol "Cholesterol")").
A copyrighted "heart-check" symbol to indicate heart-healthy food was
introduced by the [American Heart
Association](/wiki/American_Heart_Association "American Heart Association") in
1995.[14]

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/A_Map_of_Womans_Heart.jpg/86px-A_Map_of_Womans_Heart.jpg)](/wiki/File:A_Map_of_Womans_Heart.jpg)

A heart-shaped "Map of Woman's Heart" (1830s)

Two burning hearts, coloured pink, illustration on a Victorian-era
[Valentine's Day](/wiki/Valentine%27s_Day "Valentine's Day") card.

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Wounded_Heart_Vinegar_Valentine_1870s.jpg/72px-Wounded_Heart_Vinegar_Valentine_1870s.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wounded_Heart_Vinegar_Valentine_1870s.jpg)

A "[Vinegar Valentine](/wiki/Vinegar_Valentine "Vinegar Valentine")" card from
the 1870s, with a red heart symbol pierced by six arrows.

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/BigPinkHeart.jpg/78px-BigPinkHeart.jpg)](/wiki/File:BigPinkHeart.jpg)

The traditional "heart shape" appears on a 1910 Valentine's Day card.

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Look_in_His_Eyes_cover.jpg/95px-Look_in_His_Eyes_cover.jpg)](/wiki/File:Look_in_His_Eyes_cover.jpg)

Sheet music cover of "Look in His Eyes", from the musical _Have a Heart_
(1913).

## Heraldry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Heart_\(symbol\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Heraldry")]

"Heart field" or "heart shield" are terms for an
[inescutcheon](/wiki/Inescutcheon "Inescutcheon") placed _en surtout_.

The earliest heart-shaped charges in heraldry appear in the 12th century; the
hearts in the [coat of arms of Denmark](/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Denmark "Coat of
arms of Denmark") go back to the royal banner of the kings of Denmark, in turn
based on a seal used as early as the 1190s. However, while the charges are
clearly heart-shaped, they did not in origin depict hearts, or symbolize any
idea related to love. Instead they are assumed to have depicted the leaves of
the [water-lily](/wiki/Nuphar "Nuphar"). Early heraldic heart-shaped charges
depicting the leaves of water-lilies are found in various other designs
related to territories close to rivers or a coastline (_e.g._ [Flags of
Frisia](/wiki/Flags_of_Frisia "Flags of Frisia")).

Inverted heart symbols have been used in heraldry as stylized
[testicles](/wiki/Testicle "Testicle") (_coglioni_ in Italian) as in the
[canting arms](/wiki/Canting_arms "Canting arms") of the
[Colleoni](/wiki/Colleoni "Colleoni") family of Milan.[15]

A seal attributed to [William, Lord of
Douglas](/wiki/William_IV,_Lord_of_Douglas "William IV, Lord of Douglas") (of
1333) shows a heart shape, identified as the heart of [Robert the
Bruce](/wiki/Robert_the_Bruce "Robert the Bruce"). The authenticity of this
seal is "very questionable",[16] i.e. it could possibly date to the late 14th
or even the 15th century.[17]

Heraldic charges actually representing hearts became more common in the early
modern period, with the [Sacred Heart](/wiki/Sacred_Heart "Sacred Heart")
depicted in [ecclesiastical heraldry](/wiki/Ecclesiastical_heraldry
"Ecclesiastical heraldry"), and hearts representing love appearing in
bourgeois coats of arms. Hearts also later became popular elements in
municipal coats of arms.

## Botanical Symbolism :
Silphium[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Heart_\(symbol\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Botanical SymbolismÂ : Silphium")]

Main article: [Silphium](/wiki/Silphium "Silphium")

There has been some conjecture regarding the link between the traditional
heart symbol and images of the fruit of Silphium, a (probably) extinct plant
known to [classical antiquity](/wiki/Classical_antiquity "Classical
antiquity") and belonging to the genus [Ferula](/wiki/Ferula "Ferula"), used
as a condiment and medicine, (the medicinal properties including
[contraceptive](/wiki/Contraceptive "Contraceptive") and
[abortifacient](/wiki/Abortifacient "Abortifacient") activity, linking the
plant to sexuality and love).[19] Silver coins from the ancient Libya of the
6th to 5th centuries BCE bear images strongly reminiscent of the heart symbol,
sometimes accompanied by images of the Silphium plant.[20][21] The related
Ferula species [Asafoetida](/wiki/Asafoetida "Asafoetida") \- which was
actually used as an inferior substitute for Silphium - is regarded as an
[aphrodisiac](/wiki/Aphrodisiac "Aphrodisiac") in [Tibet](/wiki/Tibet "Tibet")
and [India](/wiki/India "India"), suggesting yet a third amatory association
relating to Silphium.[22]

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/5a/Cyrenecoin.jpg/120px-Cyrenecoin.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cyrenecoin.jpg)

Ancient silver coin from [Cyrene, Libya](/wiki/Cyrene,_Libya "Cyrene, Libya")
depicting the heart-shaped 'seed' (actually fruit) of Silphium.

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Illustration_Heracleum_sphondylium0.jpg/76px-Illustration_Heracleum_sphondylium0.jpg)](/wiki/File:Illustration_Heracleum_sphondylium0.jpg)

Example of a heart-shaped [mericarp](/wiki/Schizocarp "Schizocarp") fruit in a
plant (_[Heracleum sphondylium](/wiki/Heracleum_sphondylium "Heracleum
sphondylium")_) belonging, like the unidentified Silphium, to the Parsley
family, [Apiaceae](/wiki/Apiaceae "Apiaceae").

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Ferula_assa-foetida_-_K%C3%B6hler%E2%80%93s_Medizinal-Pflanzen-061.jpg/93px-Ferula_assa-foetida_-_K%C3%B6hler%E2%80%93s_Medizinal-Pflanzen-061.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ferula_assa-foetida_-_K%C3%B6hler%E2%80%93s_Medizinal-Pflanzen-061.jpg)

_[Ferula assa-foetida](/wiki/Ferula_assa-foetida "Ferula assa-foetida")_ a
species of Giant Fennel belonging to the same genus as the ancient Silphium
and regarded as having similar properties, while being an inferior substitute
for the plant.

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ferula_tingitana.jpg/81px-Ferula_tingitana.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ferula_tingitana.jpg)

_[Ferula tingitana](/wiki/Ferula_tingitana "Ferula tingitana")_ : a possible
identity for Silphium.

##
Parametrisation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Heart_\(symbol\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Parametrisation")]

A number of [parametrisations](/wiki/Parametrisation "Parametrisation") of
approximately heart-shaped [curves](/wiki/Mathematical_curve "Mathematical
curve") have been described. The best-known of these is the
[cardioid](/wiki/Cardioid "Cardioid"), which is an
[epicycloid](/wiki/Epicycloid "Epicycloid") with one
[cusp](/wiki/Cusp_\(singularity\) "Cusp \(singularity\)");[23] though as the
cardioid lacks the point, it may be seen as a stylized water-lily leaf, a so-
called [seeblatt](/wiki/Seeblatt "Seeblatt"), rather than a heart. Other
curves, such as the [implicit curve](/wiki/Level_set "Level set")
(x2+y2âˆ’1)3âˆ’x2y3=0, may produce better approximations of the heart shape.[24]
